Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was great. Very knowledgable and happy to help us.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  It would have been great if she had a larger presence in the class. Her input was very valuable.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Appreciate willingness to provide extra help and comments on manuscript throughout

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was an excellent teaching assistant. She was very accessible and always able to answer questions or point us in the right direction. She was positive and easy to talk to. She was also especially helpful with the data analysis portion of the course -- she patiently helped us through using Excel efficiently and effectively to handle our data.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  No complaints about Meredith. She always offered good suggestions for changes to our plan, and she was integral in our plant ID-ing. The Excel tutorial was very helpful, even for those of us who use Excel often.

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was great. Any time we needed extra help outside of class (which was quite frequently) she made herself available to support us. She is clearly very qualified in these matters and was great to work with.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course is extremely demanding, but it is an excellent synthesis of all of the material learned in Stands, Sampling, Silviculture. Dr. Mark Ashton is a great mentor and guides you through the material, but he is "hands off" enough to really push you to learn and apply the material yourself.

The field trips could be cut a little shorter. The exercises were extremely valuable (namely the site classification and soils), but we could talk more in a classroom and spend less time standing around in the woods before the exercises begin.

This course is essential for anyone interested in land management, field work, or becoming a naturalist. Hands down, this was the best course I've ever taken. It synthesized much of what I've learned at F&ES and gave me the opportunity to incorporate and understand much of what I'd learned before returning to graduate school. Mark is also one of the few teachers who gives substantial feedback throughout the course. Though it was a lot of work, I benefited immensely from this course and Mark's teaching.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I appreciated the knowledge and technical skills we gained throughout the course and ending with a tangible product that we could share with potential employers. I also really enjoyed the opportunity to spend so much time in the field!
Course provides a lot of applicable skills and holistic knowledge

It was a practical, synthesis of many concepts and activities that are necessary for individuals going into forestry. Participating in a consulting project from design to implementation and finally to synthesis through a published document is indispensable.

The best aspects of the course were the field work and the plan writing. In the course, you develop your own sampling design for the property, which forces you to really think about what data you need to collect, and how you can collect it in the most efficient way possible. Writing the plan was also a great exercise in explaining complex material to a lay audience.
Experience using publishing software, practicing tree ID, working with real landowners, presenting in a professional way to a landowner, and writing management recommendations.

The synthesis of field work, observation, and analysis. The deep look into a piece of land (which can really represent many places in Southern New England). I gained several hard skills (Excel, GIS, soil and plant taxonomy) relevant to future career interests. The feeling of connection and satisfaction from getting to know a piece of land better than any I've ever known. Making a final document that I'm actually proud of - a product to show employers and others. Mark is an excellent teacher and mentor. This course is essential for MF candidates - it ties together everything else we've studied into a single application/use.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Sometimes assignments, expectations of the course were unclear

It would be beneficial to incorporate a workshop on the Adobe suite programs and possibly a workshop on forest inventory software such as FVS and NED. Though this would require more time for the class which is already lengthy.

The only thing that really would have been helpful would be better communication between the professor and the students, especially regarding when materials were due. Often, we would receive emails just a day or two in advance (or sometimes even the day of) telling us when assignments were due. It is good to have flexibility in terms of due dates, based on the pace of the class, but it is also important to set clear expectations at least a week in advance so that students have time to adequately prepare. Likewise, it would be better if the readings were posted further in advance of class time, so we had more than one or two nights to read 100+ pages of material.

I would give students a heads up that they will need to have a publishing software on their laptop or be prepared to use school computers. A tutorial on inDesign or some simpler publishing software could be helpful. I probably would have used a different software if I had known how difficult it would be to print the plan using its file type. Some computer expertise probably could have prevented that hassle.

It seems like this course is pretty much figured out - given that Mark has taught it for a long time, I think most of the kinks are worked out. One thing that I'm not actually sure if I'd change is that I felt like the constant due dates for rough drafts meant that we ended up doing things multiple times. Sometimes the initial expectations weren't entirely clear, so we ended up redoing the work in a completely different way. I hesitate to say this needs to change: I understand that the frequent due dates for specific parts of the management plan are probably necessary to keep us on track and on time. Also, it isn't the worst thing to have to redo an assignment - usually the second attempt is far better.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: By the last third of the class, the lectures could have been shortened quite a bit they could have been reduced to about an hour long and have the rest of the class be work time.
Yes, they were complementary.
N/A

The lectures in class were less useful than those in the field. The geology lecture in particular could be shorter, and the stakeholder lecture from Mary Tyrrell was not very useful (though it was interesting).

The relationship between the lectures and labs were great. The biophysical parts of the course (plants, wildlife, soils, geology, sampling) were especially well done. The social aspects were a little looser, and it seemed like a little too much time may have been spent on them. In particular, I felt like the soils and plants sections were exceptional.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course fits into my overall program because it has taught me more about the natural history of the area that I want to work in and more about how to cultivate good landowner relationships which is something is good for anyone working in the forestry field to know.

This class is really the culmination of all of those that come before it in the MF curriculum. One of the reasons that I chose this program was because of this class. It provides excellent experience working with a client and applying all that you've learned in the first half of the MF program. It did not disappoint.

This course is at the center of my studies. I plan on working as a field forester / land manager, and this course is essential for my preparation. Many of my other courses (from undergrad as well) added to my understanding in this course.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I enjoy the professor and thought that the knowledge would be valuable for my future career.
Recommended as capstone class for MF degree

I took this course because I wanted to gain experience working with a client and practicing the principles that I'd learned last year in the program. It is also amazing to have a real "product" to add to a portfolio at the completion of the MF program (i.e. a certified management plan). The huge amount of work that this course requires is absolutely worth it, in my opinion.
Capstone project

Initially, I took this because I like Mark's teaching style and I know he's a good teacher who puts a lot of work into his classes. I also wanted the opportunity to craft a product in graduate school that I'm really proud of (which I did in this course).

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Yes
Yes
Yes.
yes
Yes, though I wish we could spend more time on soils since the Soil Science class doesn't quite give us the necessary background to ID soils.

They exceeded my expectations. I found that I was drawn to several topics, and I was able to really dive into these. Also, I ended up doing almost all of the quantitative analyses and mapping for my group, so I was able to really develop some proficiency in GIS and Excel. I feel like I could actually do just about everything in this class at a professional level, given I have enough experience in the local context of where I've practicing.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The advantages of working in a group are that we could not have gotten as much work done without working in a group.
Class work was very heavy on groupwork, but had a very positive group experience, making it a good part of the course. Would have been very challenging if group was not a good fit.

Group work was essential for this project. Being able to sample with a partner was crucial. On the other hand, my partner was not a very good writer, so I shouldered the entire written portion of the management plan, which was very difficult and time consuming. But that comes with the territory of group work, and I was happy that, in the end, we developed a decent product. Another advantage of the group work was that it helped me to realize where my strengths and weaknesses are as an aspiring forester. I was able to help with plant identification, the development of management recommendations, and plan writing, but I was weak when it came to using GIS and classifying soils. My partner was stronger in these areas, so it was really fortunate to be able to play off of each others strengths while realizing the areas that we each need to develop during the rest of our time here.

Overall it was a great experience. It taught me to divide work based on our relative strengths and weaknesses and how to be accountable to another person. The only disadvantage was proofreading sections of the plan that were written in broken English--it was very time consuming, and some help editing would be nice for those working with international students.

Advantages: the sampling load for this project was too high for one person. Also, in theory, having other interpretations of what you're experiencing is critical. Disadvantages: In practice, as with most group projects I've had at F&ES, the more motivated student (in this case, I believe this is myself) does more of the work. I felt like I was constantly trying to motivate my group to take things to a higher level and to do the work on-time so we could get the appropriate feedback. My group was not particularly interested in the mapping or the interpretation of the landscape, so I felt like I was making almost all of the critical decisions with the management plan. As the course went on, this problem grew, as I had made so many of the early decisions that the final recommendations were based off of my analyses and interpretations. It seems like one of the primary reasons for group projects is to share in the analyses and decision-making process. Part of the problem is that they were always behind me - I didn't want to procrastinate, so I was always thinking about this class when they seemed to prioritize their other courses or research. I had done other substantial group projects at F&ES and they had been put off until the final weeks, with disastrous results. It also seemed like my group deferred all judgement to myself, I think because they knew I had high expectations and it would get done even if they didn't take charge. A little bit of a "tragedy of the commons, perhaps? I don't have any useful advice on how to solve this problem - it seems like a perennial issue with group projects. In any case, my group was good to work with in most ways (great at field work), and maintained a positive attitude, which were greatly appreciated. The document looks amazing - due to their effort. I'm very happy with the final result we came up with.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it.
Keeping up with the work load and attending field trips and classes
The class is a 6 credit course for a reason. Plan accordingly. But, get ready for the best class maybe ever.

I would absolutely recommend taking this course if you are an MF... and even you are not. There was one MEM who took the course and got a lot out of it (I think). It is a great course for learning the process of assessing a piece of land, assessing the needs and values of different stakeholders, and developing a plan to manage the land in a socially and ecologically sound manner.

Do not graduate from the Master of Forestry program without taking this class! Even if you don't work in the field or even in America later on, it teaches valuable skills like time management, working with clients, producing a professional-grade product, and teamwork.

It's a great course - do not pass this up! Be prepared to spend most of your semester on this. Do not get behind - make sure you pay attention during the lectures and labs so you can get the assignments in on-time to take full advantage of Mark and Meredith's feedback (a level of feedback which is rare at F&ES). It is really tough and exhausting but the most "real" and satisfying thing I've done in graduate school and a project I'm proud of.
